headline: Manchester United's £26m transfer gamble already looks like a good move thanks to Man City
body: Ross joined the MEN in August 2021. He was appointed Sport Content Editor in February 2022.

Barcelona president Joan Laporta claimed last week that it had been Marcus Rashford's "dream to play for Manchester United for the rest of his life". That dream has been off the table for quite some time.
With Rashford's United career clearly over and the club desperate to raise funds for further incomings, a permanent exit for Rashford was the priority when the window opened.

It soon became evident a permanent move would not be found, with United forced to take the next best option in allowing Rashford to move to Barcelona on a season-long loan with an option to buy. €30million (£26m) is claimed to be the fee required for the Catalan club to sign Rashford next summer, but if they opt against - as Aston Villa did just a few months ago - it leaves United in a sticky situation.
The move is something of a gamble on United's part, but judging by the events unfolding on the other side of Manchester, it's already looking like a gamble that was worth taking.

United's plan to move Rashford on always had the chance of being complicated by Jack Grealish's situation at Manchester City. Granted, Rashford and Grealish are very different players, but the two forwards were always likely to be linked with big hitters across Europe.

It was imperative United moved swiftly to avoid complications later in the window. They've done just that, albeit without sanctioning the permanent exit they'd hoped for, while City are left to search for a suitor for a player who wasn't even named in their Club World Cup squad.
The longer Grealish remains a City player, the weaker their hand will be in any negotiations.

Unlike Rashford at United, Grealish took part in City training this week as the players returned from their summer break, but that looks like being the closest Grealish will come to playing alongside his teammates again.
Grealish needs to find a way out of the Etihad as much as City need to offload him. It's far from an ideal situation, and one United have avoided with Rashford.
Even if they've been made to wait for the sale they wanted.

headline: RAILSTON: Manchester United have mocked what rival fans claimed in transfer window
body: Manchester United were at rock bottom after losing in the Europa League final in May.

Defeat against Tottenham at the Estadio de San Mames meant a trophy was not salvaged from the club's worst season in 51 years. It also meant there would be no European football at Old Trafford in 2025/2026.
Pundits suggested the consequences would be grave, while the fans of rival Premier League clubs said United would struggle to attract new signings in the summer transfer window.
Although United must make a few high-quality signings to consider the summer a success, the window isn't unfolding like some pundits and rival supporters suggested it would.
"Who would want to join United?" they asked. Matheus Cunha was linked with other clubs, but the Brazilian wanted a move to Old Trafford and his transfer from Wolves was straightforward.

During Cunha's unveiling interview, he said: “It is the most common phrase that you can say at this moment, but this is the dream come true. Maybe outside, I think maybe my decision, they don’t understand. But when you have always dreamed to play here, it’s easier to pick this decision.
“For me, no-one else is like United. Of course, I know it’s been a hard season for everyone. I think my decision shows what this club is for me, and what I believe this club can be.

“It is hard to find a way to explain this club for me. My house didn’t have the channel to watch the Premier League. My cousin’s house didn’t have the channel. He’s older than me and he supports United and he showed me the way, to start to watch the Premier League and to need to support United."

Then Bryan Mbeumo arrived from Brentford for £65million and £6m in add-ons. United said Mbeumo made it clear from the outset his desire to join and never budged from that position, despite the feeling that Brentford wanted the forward to join Newcastle or Tottenham.

Mbeumo was also linked to Arsenal, but again, was adamant about moving to United. “Manchester is a big club. I think it’s a great opportunity. I’m someone who likes a challenge. There is a very good project in Manchester and I wanted to be part of it," he said in the USA this week.
"He [Amorim] said, ‘We are people who like winning, and we want to be the best team’, and of course that’s what we will try to do. It was a very friendly conversation and a constructive one.

"He explained his project to me, what he wanted to do and I really clicked on that. Of course I spoke to some other managers because I wanted to hear their projects but the Manchester United one was very good for me.”
Old Trafford was another pull. “You want to play on the greatest stages in the world, and Old Trafford is one of them, so being able to play here every two weeks is just big," said Mbeumo.
Cunha and Mbeumo received interest from elsewhere and both pushed for transfers to United, despite the club having just suffered its worst season in modern history. Why? The answer is pretty simple.
United are a giant football club, one of the biggest in the world, and the attraction of representing a club steeped in rich history and tradition is still enough to turn the head of some players.

That pull can only go so far, of course. There needs to be a project, a convincing manager and big wages offered to attract the best, but this summer has proven United's reputation still means something.
That reputation may also help United sign Benjamin Sesko from RB Leipzig, despite the striker having been identified as Newcastle's priority target amid uncertainty with Alexander Isak.

Sesko is believed to prefer a move to Manchester instead of St. James' Park. Eddie Howe's side have finished above United for successive seasons, they have just won the Carabao Cup and will play in the Champions League again, but the indication is Sesko prefers a switch to United.
Manchester United have endured a train wreck 12 months - but are still hugely attractive.

headline: Man United transfer news LIVE - Benjamin Sesko progress, Rasmus Hojlund future, Alejandro Garnacho update
body: Hello and welcome back to the Manchester United transfer blog on Thursday, July 31.

Those of you who decided to stay up overnight may well be feeling tired but shall be delighted with what you witnessed in Chicago. United continued their unbeaten start to pre-season with an exceptional 4-1 victory against AFC Bournemouth.

Rasmus Hojlund opened the scoring, before Patrick Dorgu, Amad and youngster Ethan Williams added gloss to the scoreline. The only blotch on the performance was an own goal from Matthijs de Ligt but it would do little to dampen the enthusiasm for that display.

Away from pre-season, United's main focus is now a move for RB Leipzig's Benjamin Sesko. The Reds are advancing their approach for the Slovenian after discovering that the pursuit of Ollie Watkins was unlikely to be fruitful.
The determination to sign Sesko has led to questions over Hojlund's future which Amorim addressed in Chicago overnight.
Take a look at all the United news, views and rumours in our dedicated blog below
Barcelona star Frenkie de Jong has made a decision on his future after previous transfer links with Manchester United.
The Dutch midfielder was heavily linked with a move to Old Trafford in the summer of 2022, having previously been under the guidance of then-United manager Erik ten Hag at Ajax.
Read more here
Gary Neville believes Manchester United should prioritise a new goalkeeper next in the summer transfer window - but he's wrong.

The Reds' current No.1, Andre Onana, has struggled badly at times since arriving at Old Trafford from Inter Milan in 2023. The Cameroonian was supposed to be an upgrade on a declining David de Gea and yet he has often cost United points rather than rescuing them.
Every side with ambitions to be a top team needs a world-class goalkeeper between the sticks. Onana is clearly not that based on his performances at Old Trafford over the past two seasons.
Read the full piece here

New Manchester United signing Bryan Mbeumo has already given his backing to their potential move for Ollie Watkins - who could become the Reds' equivalent of Mo Salah. Watkins, 29, featured alongside Mbeumo during their time together at then-Championship outfit Brentford in the 2019-20 campaign.
The attacking partnership netted a total of 40 goals as the Bees came agonisingly close to securing promotion to the Premier League, ultimately falling short in the play-off final against Fulham.
Read more here
Gary Neville believes Manchester United still have work to do in the transfer window this summer.

United are desperate need of a consistent goal-scorer up-front, having netted just 44 goals in the top-flight last season, their lowest total in the Premier League era. After splurging big on Matheus Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo in the current transfer window, United will need to sell players to finance additional acquisitions.
Read more here
It's already been a busy summer for Manchester United and they're not done yet.
Matheus Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo are the marquee signings of the summer so far, and while they will certainly help to sharpen a blunt attack, United still need to sign a centre-forward.
The club are advancing with a potential move for RB Leipzig striker Benjamin Sesko, while Aston Villa star Ollie Watkins is also on their radar. Whatever happens, United need a striker.
With so much going on, here's a look at all of United's transfer business so far this summer...
Jadon Sancho is prepared to take a pay cut to join Borussia Dortmund, the club where he first made a name for himself.
This is according to German outlet BILD who report that Sancho is willing to cut his pay by 50% if it means he can join the Bundesliga side.
With his slashed pay, Sancho would earn around £7m-a-year. This would still put him near the top of the highest earners at Dortmund.
Nicolas Jackson has spoken on his future amid transfer interest from Manchester United.
"Competition? I have no competition,” Jackson said, via the Metro.
"We’re all here to help the club. Everyone has their role to play. I’m on a mission. It’s up to the coach to make his choices. I focus solely on my work.
"I’m a Chelsea player. The future belongs to God. If there are any changes, you’ll know. For now, I’m focused on my preparation."
Manchester United have shifted their focus from Ollie Watkins to Benjamin Sesko, but an interesting development may yet see them return for the Aston Villa player.

Villa's valuation of Watkins seemed to be a hurdle, with United hesitant to shell out nearly £60million for the 29-year-old. Unai Emery's team were initially unwilling to sell due to their limited attacking options, but they are now considering alternatives.

Interestingly, Villa's primary attacking target is Sesko's RB Leipzig teammate Lois Openda. Reports from Belgium suggest that the Premier League club have been contemplating a move for Openda for several months, and the interest appears to be reciprocated...
Rasmus Hojlund is aware that he isn't Ruben Amorim's first choice striker and that a new No.9 is bound to be signed this summer according to transfer expert Graeme Bailey.

He told TBR Football: "Rasmus Hojlund knows he is not wanted by Man United as first choice, he knows they have been talking to strikers all summer – let’s not forget they were trying for Liam Delap in early July. Now it is Benjamin Sesko.

"United have not directly told him he can leave, and vice-versa, Hojlund has not demanded to leave – but I am told they have talked and he knows where he stands. If Sesko or another new number nine arrives, Hojlund is likely to leave."
Ruben Amorim revealed he is happy with his new squad following a busy summer transfer window.

He said after Manchester United's 4-1 victory over Bournemouth last night: "It's just pre-season, but the feeling with the same players, if I look at the same players now playing, it looks like a different team. And that is a good sign.
"The important thing is that Rasmus is scoring goals, connecting really well with the team and improving.
"I don't know what is going to happen until the [transfer] market is closed.
"I'm really happy with the players I had last season," he continued. "They are improving. We looked like a different team today. Let's continue with that.

"I'm really happy with Bryan, Matheus, even Diego. You can see it, he is a smart guy. For a guy that came from Paraguay, to come to the Premier League, he's really powerful. So I'm really happy with these three guys."
It is easy to understand why some Manchester United supporters have reservations about the club's pursuit of RB Leipzig striker Benjamin Sesko.

After all, United turned to a young and inexperienced striker in the form of Rasmus Hojlund two years ago to become the focal point of their attack, and it is fair to say that experiment has not gone well.
The Dane, who joined United from Atalanta in August 2023 for an initial fee of £64million, scored just ten goals in all competitions last season, chipping in with just four in the Premier League.
As a result, United have been left with no choice but to prioritise the addition of a new striker this summer...
Juventus will be 'ready on the market' if one of their key wingers leaves, with Jadon Sancho a viable option this summer.

Juventus General Manager Damien Comolli said, via Fabrizio Romano: “We have two of the best wingers in the world like [Kenan] Yildiz and [Chico[ Conceicao, plus Nico who’s an excellent player. If someone leaves, we will be ready on the market."
Manchester United are said to be in talks with Gianluigi Donnarumma despite reports attempting to shut down these rumours.

Bundesliga expert Jan Aage Fjortoft shared on X this morning: "Donnarumma and Manchester United. There were some reports yesterday that this was a non-starter. That’s not correct! Just been told that this process is ON. There are talks going on."
The Paris Saint-Germain keeper reportedly has a £34.6m price-tag. United had a loan deal request turned down by Aston Villa for Emi Martinez earlier this month.
Rasmus Hojlund insists he wants to stay at Manchester United and fight for his place.
Hojlund scored twice in United's 4-1 thrashing of Bournemouth in Chicago on Wednesday night, hours after it emerged United were advancing with a move for RB Leipzig striker Benjamin Sesko.

When asked if United had updated him on his future, Hojlund said: "Nothing so far. I think the most important thing for me is just to keep working hard and stay focused and then obviously we'll see what happens.
"I think my plan is very clear and that is for me to stay and fight for my spot, whatever happens..."
Rasmus Hojlund impressed in Manchester United's 4-1 victory over Bournemouth last night, scoring a goal within the opening 10 minutes.

Despite being heavily linked with a departure from Old Trafford, the 22-year-old revealed post-match that he his ready to fight for his spot at the club and is fine with competition in the striking department.

He said: "My plan is very clear. That is for me to stay and fight for my spot, whatever happens. Competition is fine with me. It sharpens me. I'm more than ready. I'm feeling sharp so I welcome everything that comes."
Speaking to BetVictor, who offer the latest online casino games, former United defender Gary Pallister has tipped James McAtee to potentially become the Reds' very own Cole Palmer.

Could we see James McAtee at United? I watched him for England’s under 21s and he looks a terrific player. I've seen him bits and bobs in the Man City first team and he's like a Cole Palmer, isn't he? He's that good a player and he doesn't want to wait around and wait for his chance. Phil Foden did. I think he could have gone down the same route as Palmer and now maybe McAtee. But he had the patience to see it out and got his rewards. I understand players wanting to play more, he knows he's talented enough to be playing in a Premier League team, but he's missing out at the moment. So I understand the frustration. Pep Guardiola has always said he would never stand in the way of anybody who wanted to leave. It's just a tough decision for the kid. He obviously loves it at Man City and wants to play there, but when you get into that age and you're not playing and you're that good… you can certainly understand the frustration. Would he come to Manchester United? I don't know. It's the Liverpool and Marcus Rashford situation, it is very difficult to get deals done between two clubs like that.
While on the surface it seems like a wise idea to try and get Saudi clubs to buy unwanted players, in practice it is harder to achieve this goal.
For the most part, this is due to players having ambitions to stay in Europe - not every player is like Joao Felix.
Antony, for instance, has reportedly already turned down a move to Brazil to stay in Europe which will be a concern for the Reds if they were to receive a bid from the Middle East.
According to Football Insider, United are looking into the possibility of selling players to the Saudi Pro League.
While no exact names have been mentioned in relation to being sold, Garnacho, Antony, Sancho and Malacia have all requested to leave Old Trafford.
The Middle East has become synonymous with big wages but now also big transfer fees with Chelsea banking £43.7m for Joao Felix.
One brief worry for United fans waking up this morning is that new signing Cunha was not in the squad that beat Bournemouth.
Fans will remember last summer that Leny Yoro picked up a severe injury during the pre-season tour of the US and United do not need history repeating itself.
Thankfully, Amorim explained Cunha's absence and it is nothing too serious.
MORE HERE
With the pursuit of Sesko now intensifying, that only adds to the speculation surrounding the future of Hojlund.
Since arriving at the club, the Dane has been the first choice centre-forward and whether his performances have merited that position or not is up for debate.
What isn't up for debate is that this move to try and sign Sesko will clearly lead Hojlund to question whether he is best sticking at United and fighting for his place, or moving elsewhere.
Yesterday, MEN Sport brought you the news that Benjamin Sesko was now United's top target in the summer transfer window.
United had been weighing up whether to target him over Ollie Watkins.
However, Villa are adamant that Watkins will be remaining at their club and thus United have decided to turn their attention to Sesko.
MORE HERE
Nicolas Jackson has flattered to deceive at Chelsea.
Last season, he averaged a goal every three Premier League matches which is hardly the sort of return that shall spark unparalleled excitement.
He is still at the early stages of his career but is two years older than Sesko.
In truth, choosing not to sign Jackson is perhaps no bad thing.
MEN Sport understands that United currently have no interest in swapping Garnacho with Chelsea's Nicolas Jackson.
Chelsea are thought to still be interested in a move for Garnacho.
However, there is no desire from the Reds to bring in Jackson as part of that deal.
MORE HERE
If he were to leave after suddenly becoming surplus to requirements, a move to Italy has been highly talked about.
Hojlund's standing in Serie A remains high after his performances for Atalanta.
Inter were credited with interest previously, as have Juventus as they look to replace Dusan Vlahovic.
From the end of last season, talk has been rife about the future of Hojlund with the striker asked on international duty if he was set to leave.
He replied then that his plan was to be at United this season and that was all he is focused on.
This stance has been reflected on the rumour mill too with journalist Fabrizio Romano among those to state that his preference is to remain at Old Trafford.
Speaking to the assembled media in the US, Ruben Amorim was unable to give any guarantees that Hojlund would be staying at United beyond this summer.
He explained:

I am really happy with Rasmus. I don't know what is going to happen until the end of the market. The important thing is that the strikers that are here are working really well, are improving, are helping the team and that is the most important thing. The important thing is that Rasmus is scoring goals. He's connecting really well with the team. He's improving. Again, I don't know what is going to happen until the market is closed.

Hello and welcome to the United transfer blog this Thursday morning.
My name is Jack Flintham and I shall be taking you through until lunchtime with all the latest United news.
We shall start with reaction to the victory over Bournemouth where the latest on this man's future was discussed...
RB Leipzig are demanding a fee of £64million plus add-ons as well as a sell-on percentage for a deal for Benjamin Sesko, as per The Athletic.
Manchester United have made Sesko their first-choice striker option and want to agree a deal for the Slovenian before the end of the summer transfer window.
Barcelona head coach Hansi Flick has admitted he has been monitoring Marcus Rashford's career for some time now, following his summer loan move from Manchester United.

Speaking in a press conference on Wednesday, Flick said: "Rashford? I've been following him for many years, ever since he started his career at Man United. We hope he can show his quality this season."

headline: Frenkie de Jong makes Barcelona transfer statement as Manchester United watch on
body: Barcelona star Frenkie de Jong has made a decision on his future after previous transfer links with Manchester United.
The Dutch midfielder was heavily linked with a move to Old Trafford in the summer of 2022, having previously been under the guidance of then-United manager Erik ten Hag at Ajax.

The Dutchman started in Barca's 7-3 win over FC Seoul in his team's second game of their Asia Tour on Thursday. De Jong has made 259 appearances for Barcelona since joining the club in 2019 from Ajax.
And he now looks to stay in Catalonia for the foreseeable future. The 28-year-old has confirmed that he will sign a new contract with the La Liga champions.
“Yes, I’m gonna sign new deal with Barcelona," he said via Fabrizio Romano on X (Twitter).
“I’m very happy at the club, I didn’t sign yet but it’s gonna happen.”
Midfield is a priority position the Reds are targeting this summer. Uncertainty still surrounds the future of Casemiro, while Christian Eriksen has left after his contract expired at the end of June.
Meanwhile, Kobbie Mainoo has turned down the opening offer of a new deal from United during negotiations.

headline: Juventus chief makes Douglas Luiz 'disrespect' claim after Man United transfer demand
body: Manchester United-linked midfielder Douglas Luiz was forced to apologise after disrespecting his Juventus teammates, according to general director Damien Comolli. The former Aston Villa star faces an uncertain future in Turin with reports suggesting that he could return to the Premier League after leaving for Serie A last summer.

According to Fabrizio Romano, the 27-year-old will leave the Italian giants this summer, which has sparked fresh speculation surrounding his future. In other outlets, United have been mooted as possible suitors to add reinforcements to their midfield after adding Matheus Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo to their attacking firepower.
Football Insider claimed in mid-July that United had registered their interest in the Juventus midfielder.
It was reported at the time that they faced competition from Everton who were also reportedly targeting Luiz, despite four years remaining on his contract.
The claims suggest that it comes after the Serie A side began considering their options and were keen to offload the midfielder, preferring permanent offers over a short-term solution.
Speaking to reporters, Comolli claimed that Luiz was forced to apologise after disrespecting his teammates.
He said: “Douglas Luiz disrespected his teammates and the whole group.
"He apologised right after."
It has been claimed that the 27-year-old skipped scheduled medical tests last Thursday, which led to the club sanctioning him and placing him on the transfer list.
Luiz, it has been said, accompanied crisis talks with his agent when they met Juventus directors and manager Igor Tudor.
But the latest admission from Comolli comes days after Darts sensation and Man United fan, Luke Littler, called upon chiefs at Old Trafford to sign the midfielder.
"For myself, I’ve said for the past week… Douglas Luiz from Juventus," he began.
"It will be a no-brainer.
"Whether you want him sitting, whether you want him attacking, he can do it all.”

headline: Man United next transfer after Benjamin Sesko 'ready to go' as background checks 'complete'
body: With less than two weeks until Premier League football returns, the transfer window is ramping up as clubs look to make last minute changes to their squad before the first game of the season.
Manchester United have so far made three new additions to their squad. Young left-back Diego Leon has joined from Cerro Porteno, although he not expected to go straight into the starting line-up.

Two that will be pushing for starts are Matheus Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo. Cunha joined from Wolves for £62.5 million earlier in the summer, while Mbeumo joined from Brentford for an initial £65 million earlier this month.
United will hope that they are soon joined by Red Bull Leipzig striker Benjamin Sesko. The club are advancing with a potential move for the forward amid interest from Newcastle United.
If a deal for Sesko can be completed, then the next transfer move after that may already be being lined up, with the future of Alejandro Garnacho taking a step closer to being resolved.

As reported by the Telegraph, Chelsea maintain their interest in the United winger this summer, and is said to be the favoured destination for the player this window. The Blues are said to have made background checks on Garnacho, and hold no concerns over his character after being bombed out of the United squad by head coach Ruben Amorim.
It is added that Chelsea are expected to make an offer for the winger, but may wait until United’s search for a new striker is over.

The Blues themselves may need to create space in their squad with the sale and loan of attackers. Christopher Nkunku and Armando Broja are expected to leave permanently, while Marc Guiu and Tyrique George could complete loan moves.

Chelsea are also said to have held talks with Red Bull Leipzig over a deal for Xavi Simons, but even if he does arrive at Stamford Bridge, it would not stop a move for Garnacho happening if enough room could be made in the squad.

Latest reports suggest that United would be willing to accept an offer of around £40 million for Garnacho this summer. They are not interested in a swap deal for the winger, amid transfer links to Chelsea striker Nicolas Jackson.

headline: LUCKHURST: What Bruno Fernandes did in 69th minute vs Bournemouth typifies change in Manchester United
body: With Manchester United in discussions for a new No.9, the incumbent got two goals against Bournemouth. Rasmus Hojlund charged around like a bull in Chicago.

Hojlund's deft header in the eighth minute was smart striker play he is not synonymous with. Bournemouth were seemingly thrown by Patrick Dorgu crossing with his right foot and crossing well. Hojlund neatly helped the ball on its way.

As meaninglessly as these games are judged, they have to be meaningful for the players. That was apparent with Hojlund's celebration, identical to when he equalised at Bournemouth in added time in late April.

His evening did not start auspiciously. He kept his place but his mood was not improved by a recall for Diogo Dalot, fast becoming Hojlund's scourge. Hojlund was demonstrative with Dalot with less than four minutes on the clock, piqued that he had not read his heavy lay-off. Dalot nevertheless congratulated his teammate on his goal.

In the 51st minute, there was a bullish high-ten from Dalot for Hojlund after he was crudely fouled. Hojlund got a similar amount of contact for his second goal yet was not immediately enveloped by his teammates. Amad's shot grazed Hojlund's shin and both claimed the glory. As it stands, it is credited to Amad.

While United are in dialogue with RB Leipzig goalscorer Benjamin Sesko, Hojlund has to view his own situation as win-win. No Sesko means he continues at the tip of the arrow. If Sesko comes in, Hojlund can create a wider market for himself. Inter Milan enquired about his availability at the start of the transfer window.

There was a Danish theme to United's win, with Dorgu notching his first senior goal for the club. Dorgu has been quietly effective and more attack-minded across all three friendlies. A left back by trade, Dorgu is developing into the pure winger that Ruben Amorim's 3-4-2-1 system demands of the wide roles.

New Bournemouth goalkeeper Djordje Petrovic was flimsy for Dorgu's dink though it was a smartly-worked goal, instigated by Mason Mount's quick-thinking with a quickly-taken free kick. Dorgu invited it with his sudden charge into the final third.

United look fitter than at this stage in past pre-seasons. Every starter bar Harry Maguire, withdrawn at the interval, played for 70 minutes. Maguire's replacement, Matthijs de Ligt, put through his own net late on.

The Premier League opposition in this Summer Series appears to have reinforced United's focus. West Ham and Bournemouth both beat United last season. The intensity and edge about United was best exhibited by Bruno Fernandes.

He sprinted back to block a cross before berating the referee for awarding a corner. Teammates were quick to congratulate Fernandes, unrelenting in his criticism of official Lewis Smith. That was in the 69th minute and marked his final contribution.

Amorim downplayed the strength of the United side against West Ham last week and there were six changes in the Windy City. United still have the wind in their sails, with two wins out of two in the States.

This handsome friendly win was replete with an academy goal from a newbie. Ethan Williams, one of ten substitutes to emerge, scored within two minutes of his first senior appearance. Williams, a winger, has inherited Chido Obi's old squad number and his finish was akin to a striker's.

United were without both of their senior summer recruits as Matheus Cunha sat out the game due to fatigue. He is expected to be fit for the final tour match against Everton on Sunday in Atlanta, where Bryan Mbeumo is scheduled to appear, most likely from the bench.

The main dampener on United's pre-season on Wednesday evening was the Chicago weather. There were more ponchos than replica shirts at Soldier Field and the United players' red replicas were so saturated from the swirling rain they turned blood red.

Luke Shaw was one of the six players recalled, slotting in on the left of the back three. He does not have the durability to be entrusted with the left wing role and he may be at the back of the queue at centre back when Lisandro Martinez ends his rehabilitation.

Amorim generously dubbed Shaw "world class" last week. "He understands the problems I had last season were really tough," Shaw said on Tuesday. "It's something I've not experienced, to be honest. I know I've had a lot of injuries, but it was more mentally how tough it was. It was really tough. I think last season was one to forget really. Like I said, I've had injuries in the past, but last season it was different kinds of injuries.

"It was horrible. To be fair, it started with a calf and I've never had a calf injury in my life, so I was never used to that. It was just a completely different rehab and stuff. Things just kept happening. It was really stressful."
Shaw was anything but with a couple of well-read recovery tackles. He required treatment from the physio following an impact injury but soldiered on at Soldier Field.
So is Hojlund.

headline: What Marcus Rashford did in second Barcelona game speaks volumes for Man United amid £26m update
body: Manchester United loannee Marcus Rashford made another strong impression during his second Barcelona appearance after looking bright on his debut.

Just three days after having his temporary switch confirmed, the England international came on at half time against Vissel Kobe before being brought off in the 78th minute with his minutes being managed having just arrived at the La Liga champions.
With more training sessions likely under his belt, Rashford played a full half this time as Hansi Flick's side beat FC Seoul 7-3 as part of their pre-season tour in Asia.

Though four goals were scored while he was on the pitch, Rashford failed to get off the mark - but he did grab the assist for Ferran Torres' late goal with a very smart pass in behind which allowed the former Manchester City man to finish easily.

Prior to that however, the 27-year-old was looking very sharp both coming in off the left and sprinting down the touchline. Just moments after being introduced, he skipped beyond several challenges before firing a powerful effort which was parried clear by the goalkeeper.

No less than five minutes later, Rashford opted for a run in the opposite direction with some jinking step-overs allowing him to get into a crossing position only for an interception to be made which saw Barcelona win a corner.

Considering his impact thus far and the fact that Raphinha and Lamine Yamal are both left-footed, Barcelona may be very keen to keep Rashford beyond the 2025/26 season - if he can continue making a similar impact. If they do choose to activate the buy-option inserted into his loan move, it will cost just €30million (£26m).
Though United would have hoped for more money and for it to come in this summer, Alejandro Garnacho, Jadon Sancho and Antony all look set to depart Old Trafford permanently over the coming weeks.

Any funds acquired from a Rashford sale would however, go straight onto their financial books as pure profit with the attacker also having the chance to make an impact at his dream club. That scenario playing out, based on Rashford's first two appearances, currently looks very likely.

headline: Benjamin Sesko to Manchester United latest - transfer 'stance' and Ruben Amorim response
body: Manchester United has just over a month to sign a new striker before the summer transfer window closes on September 1.

Ruben Amorim's side have so far welcomed Matheus Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo as new reinforcements, but an attacker remains high on their priority list. A number of options are being considered, including Nicolas Jackson, Ollie Watkins, and Sesko.
Speaking on his YouTube channel, Fabrizio Romano said: "Manchester United have been in contact with Benjamin Sesko's camp since last week and are also in contact with Red Bull Leipzig.

"So Man United spoke to both of them and Christopher Vivell is the name to remember. Vivell is the director of Manchester United, who used to work at RB Group then he went to Chelsea for some time and then to United.

"He has a very good relationship with RB Group and knows Sesko very well, so Vivell is working actively, helping with this deal. Man United are also showing Leipzig the opportunity to include a player into a deal for Sesko.
"Then we have to see if this player would be open to going to Leipzig because they don't play European football for many years so I don't think it will be easy to include a player in this deal."
Addressing Newcastle's interest, Romano added: "Newcastle are prepared to pay what it takes to Red Bull Leipzig to sign him. Contract terms, salary, commission, transfer fee, whatever.
"Newcastle are ready to go for Sesko. But this depends on the player and what he wants to do."

Asked about a move for an update on Sesko’s potential transfer to Old Trafford following United's 4-1 pre-season win over Bournemouth, Amorim said: "No. The important thing is Rasmus is scoring goals and connecting really well with the team.
"We look like a different team today let’s continue with that. I’m really happy with Bryan and Matheus.
"Even Diego you can see he’s a smart guy for a guy who came from Paraguay to the Premier League it’s a really powerful player I’m really happy with these three guys."
Romano also noted that the 22-year-old, who has several options on the table, will take the next few days to meet with his family and agent before deciding on his future.
Meanwhile, Sky Germany journalist Florian Plettenberg provided further insight into the situation. The striker is said to be impressed with United’s approach and their determination to secure a deal.
When the forward signed a new contract last summer, it included a clause allowing him to leave for a 'special' club.
Romano claims the gentleman's agreement between Sesko and Leipzig could see his price tag reduced to between €70-80m plus €5-10m add-ons.

If United were to sign Sesko, his preferred number may not be available. The striker currently wears No.30 at RB Leipzig - a number he also wore at Red Bull Salzburg, but it has already been taken by summer signing Diego Leon.
Sesko previously wore No.21 and No.29 earlier in his career.
While No.21 is currently assigned to Antony, the Brazilian is expected to leave the club this summer. Meanwhile, No.29 remains vacant and could be an option.

headline: 'Even more' - Patrick Dorgu makes Manchester United admission after Bournemouth win
body: Wing-back Patrick Dorgu believes Manchester United's players are putting Ruben Amorim's ideas into practice following their 4-1 win over Bournemouth at Soldier Field in Chicago.

United stepped up their pre-season preparations with a commanding victory over the Cherries in testing conditions, ensuring they maintained their 100 per cent record in the Premier League Summer Series.

Goals either side of half-time from Rasmus Hojlund, Dorgu, Amad and substitute Ethan Williams put Bournemouth to the sword before they pulled a goal back late on when United defender Matthijs de Ligt turned a David Brooks cross into his own net.

Dorgu was among a crop of individuals who produced an eye-catching performance, providing the assist for Hojlund's opener before latching onto a quickly-taken free-kick from Mason Mount to score his first goal in United colours.
Dorgu believes he and his teammates are benefitting from the time they are spending on the training ground.
"I feel like the pre-season is helping everyone to understand Ruben's ideas even more," Dorgu told MUTV. "I feel like the more training we have, the more we will grow into his ideas.
"I feel like it is being seen a little bit on the pitch, so we just have to keep improving."
Although Dorgu's goal won't go down as a competitive goal for the Reds, he was clearly elated to score for the first time in United colours since arriving from Lecce earlier this year.
After shrugging off his man, he managed to keep his cool to bury a low shot past Cherries shot-stopper Djordje Petrovic.
On his goal, Dorgu added: "It is a good ball from Mase and I just put my body in front of the defender. I was a bit lucky with the finish, to be honest, but it went in, and that's what matters."

Newcastle United are also interested in Sesko amid uncertainty over the future of Alexander Isak, who has skipped their pre-season tour.
Manchester United have launched their new away kit for the 2025/26 season, inspired by the club's early-1990s Adidas snowflake kit.

headline: 'Quite toxic' - Luke Shaw opens up on Manchester United problems
body: Luke Shaw admits the Manchester United environment has been "toxic" in recent years and head coach Ruben Amorim will not pick players who fall short of his demands.

United endured their worst season in 51 years in 2024-25 and the season ended with Amorim telling winger Alejandro Garnacho he could leave after he questioned the Portuguese's decision to bench him in the Europa League final.
Garnacho remains part of the 'bomb squad' that have been exiled from the first-team squad and ordered to train when their teammates are not on the premises at Carrington.
Marcus Rashford has joined Barcelona on a season-long loan but Antony, Jadon Sancho and Tyrell Malacia remain on United's books as they approach the final four weeks of the transfer window.

Amorim dropped Garnacho and Rashford for the Manchester derby on December 15 and the latter is unlikely to play for United again. Rashford was disciplined twice by former manager Erik ten Hag, while Sancho was banished from the squad after accusing the Dutchman of lying. Shaw acknowledged there were "no stragglers in this group any more".
"A lot of the time I’ve been here over the last few years it’s been extremely negative," Shaw said. "It can be quite toxic, the environment, it's not healthy at all.

"We need an environment that's healthy, that's positive, that's got good energy and happiness. I think when you have all those things, you feel free and you express yourself more on the pitch. Things come together and I think, especially this pre-season, I feel like us as a team, I feel like the bond is growing and growing.
"I feel like in my time here, it's probably the closest I've felt with the squad since I've been here. I think the atmosphere is really good and extremely positive. Hopefully, that can continue.

"The manager has to [take action] because at the end of the day, he's going to be the one that has his job always on the line. He wants to come in and do exactly what he wants because he's always the one who's on the end of the stick. He wants to come in and do things his own way and stamp his own authority on the club. I think that's the only way you can do it, especially at Man United.

"I think we need to just all up the level of demands. That's what I think Ruben definitely brings in, is the demands. Especially the mentality. The mentality is a big thing on his lips, really. I think he talks a lot about it. Especially in day-to-day things, with the training. Ruben demands 100% and that's it and he doesn't want anything less.
"If someone's doing 85-90%, it's not enough for him. I think, especially this year, if you're not doing the right things, I feel like you won't play.

"And he's not bothered. I think you've seen what he's done in the past eight months with different players and things like that. He doesn't care who the player is. I think if he's not following what he wants, then that's how it should be, and I think rightly so. I think whatever the manager wants, us as players we have to be delivering that. So, yes, we're fully behind that."

Shaw, 30, gave a raw interview moments after the Europa League final defeat consigned United to only a second season without European football in 35 years where he said United players had to "question whether they're good enough".

The left back has played 27 games in the two full seasons since he signed a four-year contract worth around £200,000-a-week and this is his 12th pre-season with United. Bruno Fernandes, who joined United five-and-a-half years after Shaw, overtook him for club appearances last term.
Shaw, who has started a meagre 20 United games in two years, has no regrets about his post-match candour and admitted he had "an awful year".

"I wouldn't say regret, but I think straight after the game your head's hot and you just say things and you don't think about it," he explained. "I think a lot of people after that final, after that year, had the feeling of you don't know how next season's going to look.

"I think we have to be open and honest about that. I think none of us were good enough. I think there always has to be that question about what we think and what our plans for the next season. I just don't really know what more to say about that.
"It's never easy losing a final, especially after the season that we went through. It was even harder to take. Like I said, I think that's why my head was a bit hotter than usual as well.
"I think I had such an awful year as well. I was just fully angry about everything. I just think that's why I did the interview and said what I said."

Shaw joined United 11 years ago and his first few at the club were beset by injury issues and he was publicly criticised by his managers. Louis van Gaal bluntly said Shaw was "not fit enough" during his first pre-season in 2014 and Jose Mourinho despaired at how immature Shaw conducted himself.
After Shaw was late for training once, he innocently told staff that his mother had overslept and not woken him up in time. Now Shaw is preaching the importance of punctual timekeeping.

"I think us as players, especially the more experienced ones, we need to be demanding more from a day-in, day-out basis," he added. "The levels in training, keeping the times of when we're doing this and doing that, making sure no one's coming late or anything."

headline: RAILSTON: Ruben Amorim is fixing 'toxic' Manchester United problem behind the scenes
body: The best interviews with Manchester United's players often take place in pre-season.
The players are more relaxed in a luxury setting abroad, journalists are granted more time during the sit-down and chats take place ahead of a new campaign, so there is a clean slate.

There are 'positive vibes' on pre-season tour, particularly this summer because United have reached rock bottom and the only way is up. The arrivals of Matheus Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo have boosted morale, probably just as much as Ruben Amorim's decision to axe the 'bomb squad' from his plans.
And Luke Shaw spoke to journalists in Chicago this week, producing some fascinating quotes.
"A lot of the time I’ve been here over the last few years it’s been extremely negative. It can be quite toxic, the environment, it's not healthy at all," said Shaw about the dressing room.

"We need an environment that's healthy, that's positive, that's got good energy and happiness. I think when you have all those things, you feel free and you express yourself more on the pitch. Things come together and I think, especially this pre-season, I feel like us as a team, I feel like the bond is growing and growing.
"I feel like in my time here, it's probably the closest I've felt with the squad since I've been here. I think the atmosphere is really good and extremely positive. Hopefully, that can continue.

"The manager has to [take action] because at the end of the day, he's going to be the one that has his job always on the line. He wants to come in and do exactly what he wants because he's always the one who's on the end of the stick. He wants to come in and do things his own way and stamp his own authority on the club. I think that's the only way you can do it, especially at Man United.
"I think we need to just all up the level of demands. That's what I think Ruben definitely brings in, is the demands. Especially the mentality. The mentality is a big thing on his lips, really.
"I think he talks a lot about it. Especially in day-to-day things, with the training. Ruben demands 100% and that's it and he doesn't want anything less."
Amorim did not improve results following his arrival from Sporting Lisbon, but he tackled an unhealthy culture at Carrington by laying down the law in the dressing room.
Marcus Rashford and Alejandro Garnacho were dropped from the squad to face Manchester City in December. Rashford was permanently exiled, but Garnacho was reintegrated before working his ticket again.

Both players were not included in Amorim's plans for the new campaign and the 40-year-old deserves credit for taking on two talented members of the dressing room. It would have been more convenient to give them further chances rather than outright axing them from the squad.
Amorim wants talented players who possess the right personality and character. Erik ten Hag addressed the culture during his reign, but there was more work to do when Amorim arrived in November.

Some will not want to hear from Shaw given his injury record, but he is an experienced professional and is well-positioned to provide insight, so his selection of the word 'toxic' gave a glimpse behind the curtain.

It feels like United are closer to achieving a healthy dressing room than they've ever been since 2013. Each United manager has tried to foster a perfect culture, but egos have been allowed to fester.
Amorim's work behind the scenes to create an improved culture is just as important as getting tactics right on a matchday because a sporting institution cannot succeed without strong culture.

The feeling of the squad, how players interact with each other and carry themselves away from the pitch is so important. Rashford and Garnacho had let themselves down at times and Amorim deemed that unacceptable.
The raising of standards is a huge positive ahead of the new campaign.

headline: Benjamin Sesko Man United transfer decision speaks volumes after Ollie Watkins snub
body: Manchester United's pursuit to sign a new centre-forward appeared to be leaning in the direction of Aston Villa's Ollie Watkins this summer.

However, a swerve on Wednesday has seen the Reds change course and they are now prioritising a move for RB Leipzig striker Benjamin Sesko instead. The 22-year-old is highly thought of by the director of recruitment Christopher Vivell and has already been compared to Erling Haaland.

Were this deal to be confirmed, he would not be the first player brought to Old Trafford in recent years who has been compared to the Manchester City talisman. Rasmus Hojlund was also given this rather unenviable title and suffered last season after a mixed start to life at the club.

As mentioned by our Chief United writer, Sesko is younger than Hojlund but the expectations are still plentiful for the striker. It has been too long since the Reds have had a striker capable of 20 Premier League goals and the Slovenian is being tasked with ending that streak.

But choosing to focus your energy on Sesko instead of Watkins, whether Villa wanted to sell the Englishman or not, speaks volumes for the team which Ineos are trying to build. There was relative security in the idea of signing Watkins.

He is proven in the Premier League and could perhaps continue scoring at Old Trafford. Such a pedigree comes with a price tag and he would have likely cost similar to Sesko despite having just two years remaining on his deal in the West Midlands.

What United are showing is that they are wanting to invest in players that have plenty of potential rather than those who are heading towards the final stages of their career. When those two options are put to Ineos, it appears they would prefer to go with the former rather than the latter.

Considering the situation United are in, the move also speaks volumes as to the standing the club has in world football still. When the Reds lost that Europa League final plenty of people, myself included, questioned whether United could still attract players who are wanted by Champions League clubs.
It seems that fear was unfounded. While Viktor Gyokeres may have gotten away, United have shown they still have that pull which makes some of the top, emerging talent want to join.

Of course, this deal is not yet done and United still have work to do to ensure it is completed - chief of which is making it absolutely certain that the transfer is financially affordable. However, the Reds are looking to make another standout signing in a window which could have easily gotten away from them.

headline: Man Utd star ‘signals’ decision to make ‘sacrifice’ to force transfer amid ‘heated internal debate’
body: According to reports, Manchester United flop Jadon Sancho has ‘signalled’ his intention to make a significant ‘sacrifice’ to seal his preferred transfer.
Sancho returned to Man Utd at the start of this summer’s transfer window as Chelsea decided to pay a reported £5m penalty fee to send him back to Old Trafford.
The England international had a mixed spell on loan at Chelsea as he did not do enough to earn a permanent move and his future remains in doubt.

The winger has not come close to living up to his £73m price tag since joining Man Utd from Borussia Dortmund and is not part of Ruben Amorim’s plans as club chiefs oversee a significant squad overhaul.
Since returning to Man Utd, Sancho has been linked with several Premier League and European clubs, though it is now being reported that he could return to Dortmund for a third spell.
READ: Romano reveals huge Sesko swap boost as RB Leipzig ‘dream’ of ‘damned’ Man Utd star
Sancho clearly feels comfortable at Dortmund as he has produced his best form at the Bundesliga side and a report from German outlet BILD claims he is keen on a ‘return’.
It is even noted that Sancho ‘would be willing to make some sacrifices’ to secure his desired move to Dortmund and would ‘forego’ a huge sum of money to land a move back to the Bundesliga side.
The report claims:

‘He has already signaled to the Dortmund management around boss Lars Ricken (49) and sports director Sebastian Kehl (45) that he is willing to forego a lot of salary in order to return to his feel-good club.

‘Sancho hauls in around €16 million per season at the Red Devils. In Dortmund, he would reportedly play for half of his staggering salary. That wouldn’t even put him among the top earners (Niklas Süle at €14 million), but would rank in the upper midfield.’
The report notes United are ‘not interested’ in Sancho, but Chelsea legend Roberto Di Matteo claims he could be “one of the greatest in the game”.
“I think it’s all down to Jadon Sancho. He has so much quality and so much potential to be one of the greatest in the game. I don’t know why he’s inconsistent,” Di Matteo said.

“He went back to Borussia Dortmund and managed to help them to the Champions League final, he showed us again how good he could be. It’s completely down to him. It’s completely down to him what he wants to do with his career.

“Dortmund are a big club, Juventus is even a bigger club in terms of history and titles and they’re always competing to win titles – but it’s really down to his mentality. It’s down to his mentality and his attitude.
“What does he want? Does he want to be a player that is remembered in the history of football or does he just want to keep changing teams every season? It’s down to him.”
Manchester United star Luke Shaw has given his backing to head coach Ruben Amorim and hit out at four Red Devils “stragglers”.
Borussia Dortmund are back in for Man Utd winger Jadon Sancho as the Red Devils set their asking price for the Juventus target, according to reports.
Reports have surfaced suggesting Borussia Dortmund new boy Jobe Bellingham has tried to lure an Arsenal star to the club alongside him.

Fabrizio Romano wrote on X on Tuesday: ‘Paris Saint-Germain are at final stages of Lucas Chevalier deal, here we go soon!

headline: Bruno Fernandes and the ‘experiment’ Man Utd tried 18 times last season
body: People paid to write about Manchester United are acting like Bruno Fernandes in central midfield is a ‘tactical tweak’. Keep up…
What Bruno Fernandes did in 69th minute vs Bournemouth typifies change in Manchester United

Now it takes 11 fat paragraphs before we discover exactly what Bruno Fernandes did in the 69th minute, which strongly suggests that the click-tastic headline came very much after the opinion, which quite rightly opens on the impressive Rasmus Hojlund after his goal.
So what exactly did Bruno Fernandes do in the 69th minute to ‘typify change’?
He sprinted back to block a cross before berating the referee for awarding a corner.
It sounds pretty much exactly like something Bruno Fernandes would do – in the 7th, 18th, 27th, 69th or 90th minute – and exactly like something he has always done.
‘Bright as ever’, you say. Sounds odd for a man who did something to ‘typify change’.
Meanwhile, at The Sun, we’re told that ‘Dorgu bags first goal for Red Devils to go with classy assist but Bruno Fernandes concern emerges’.
The ‘concern’ is that ‘the deeper role restricted him from doing what he does best at the other end’, which left Fernandes being awarded a mere 5/10.
Yes, that’s a real ‘concern’ as Manchester United won 4-1 without new signings Bryan Mbeumo and Matheus Cunha. Amorim won’t be able to sleep tonight.
Oh wait, he said: “Bruno is a very intelligent player, capable of controlling the tempo of the match, so I am very satisfied with him.”
It’s almost like footballers can do more than take shots and that.

Tinker, tailor, soldier, why?
The Daily Mail go big with their coverage of Manchester United’s win over Bournemouth ‘to go top of the Premier League Summer Series table’ (which might be the most unintentionally funny opening line we have read for some time).
THINGS WE LEARNED from Man United’s 4-1 thrashing of Bournemouth: Rasmus Hojlund sends message to Benjamin Sesko, Ruben Amorim’s tactical tweak, and why Matheus Cunha missed out
Obviously, Holjund’s ‘message to Benjamin Sesko’ was a goal; we are now so familiar with this nonsensical vernacular that nary an eyebrow is raised.
As for the ‘tactical tweak’…we’re intrigued. Surely it cannot be Bruno Fernandes playing in a deeper role, as that happened many, many times last season?
The Red Devils boss had promised an experiment and fans certainly got that, with Bruno Fernandes starting in a deeper role alongside Casemiro.

Oh, somebody (in this case the Mail’s actual Manchester United correspondent) was not paying attention last season, when Fernandes played in a deeper role on 18 occasions, including in the actual Europa League final v Tottenham. You might think that would stick in the mind.

Indeed, in the most important game of Ruben Amorim’s tenure – that Europa League final – United played exactly the same outfield players as in this ‘experiment’ v Bournemouth, barring the inclusion of Diogo Dalot over the injured Noussair Mazraoui.
It’s only ‘tactical tinkering’ if you haven’t been watching. And we’re starting to think we might be the only ones watching.

I got new rules, I count ’em
Have Manchester United set themselves a ‘golden rule’ to only recruit from the Premier League? It seems unlikely. And entirely impractical.

What they have decided on is – and we will consult the Daily Telegraph here – ‘the clear and deliberate targeting of players who have shown they can not only compete but thrive in Europe’s most competitive domestic league and yet who still fit the right age profile’.
Is that a ‘golden rule’? Is it balls.
And yet…
Man Utd break golden transfer rule after deciding between Benjamin Sesko and Ollie Watkins
Sesko has no Premier League experience and Watkins is the wrong age profile so presumably the Mirror were going to opt for a ‘break golden transfer rule’ headline either way. Handy.
More sodding rules than Dua Lipa.

A message to you, Ruben…
Somebody needs to tell Ollie Watkins that Manchester United have decided on Benjamin Sesko because he’s out there needlessly sending a ‘clear message to Manchester United amid Benjamin Sesko pursuit’ (TBR Football).
And how did he send this ‘clear message’? By scoring a goal, of course. Presumably if he wasn’t interested in a transfer to Manchester United, he would have missed the target.
Daniel Levy probably needs to stop offering transfer add-ons based on ‘difficult objectives’ like Spurs winning the Premier League or Champions League.
There is a definite trend to summer business – forwards whose first thought is to dribble are being prized. What does that mean for the visionaries?
Teddy Sheringham has praised Bruno Fernandes for staying at “big club” Manchester United while they “aren’t at the top of their game.”
Man Utd have spent a mere £1.7bn since Sir Alex Ferguson retired at the end of 2012/13. That’s a lot of wonga for zero Premier League titles…

England fans were so unimpressed by the drab win over Andorra that only two people wrote in about it – more were interested in defending Bruno Fernandes.

headline: Transfer rumour ranking: Benjamin Sesko ‘scared’ of Newcastle move in Man Utd boost
body: Manchester United need to decide among themselves which striker they want, but they’ve received a big boost from a “scared” Newcastle target…
With so much transfer talk doing the rounds, we’re here through the summer to sift through the bullsh*t and highlight the whispers that might have some substance.
Each day we’re ranking the top 20 rumours involving Premier League clubs, the higher the link, the more likely we feel they are to become done deals.
So we start with the tittle-tattle…

20) Darwin Nunez – Liverpool to Juventus
The Old Lady are the latest to throw their hat in the ring for Nunez, who was previously a target for Napoli. Liverpool have been keen to sell the Uruguayan striker for a while, but they are even more eager now that Alexander Isak is available. It doesn’t alter the fact that neither Juve nor Milan can afford what Liverpool are hoping to get.

19) 🆕 Lois Openda – RB Leipzig to Aston Villa
Villa are shopping around for strikers, which does hint at an exit for Ollie Watkins. Journalist Sacha Tavolieri says they are an ‘option’ for Leipzig No.9 Openda, who has scored 33 goals in 67 Bundesliga appearances.

18) 🔼 Marc Guehi – Crystal Palace to Liverpool
Football Insider’s Mick Brown is hearing things again, folks. Guehi to Liverpool could accelerate following Luis Diaz’s transfer to Bayern, apparently. The Crystal Palace captain’s “heart is set” on a move to Anfield, says the ex-Manchester United chief scout, who remains very well-connected within the game. FI’s words, not ours.

17) Leandro Trossard – Arsenal to Borussia Dortmund
The Gunners man is on Dortmund’s list of winger targets, with Jadon Sancho also under consideration. Arsenal could reinvest some of the money into Rodrygo, which means their supporters are bang up for this.

16) Gianluigi Donnarumma – PSG to Manchester United
Donnarumma has been in a contract dispute with PSG but we’re starting to think there might be more to this than his representatives using United’s name and the oldest trick in agent’s book. PSG are signing Lucas Chevalier from Lille and appear more likely to sell Donnarumma now than allow him to leave for nothing next year. United certainly need a goalkeeper, but they also need a striker and neither can be paid for with brass buttons. Still, one to watch…

15) 🆕 Samu Aghehowa – Porto to Aston Villa
The Spain international has also been linked with Newcastle but it’s Villa being mentioned as a potential destination for Aghehowa. One problem: Porto are using the Viktor Gyokeres fee as a benchmark and they want £55million. Which is more a less one whole Ollie Watkins.

14) Joao Palhinha – Bayern Munich to Tottenham
Spurs are looking for a new no.6 and while Conor Gallagher has been mentioned, there is greater clamour around Palhinha, who has been told he can leave Bayern after one season. Bayern want £30million; Spurs are chasing a discount. If they get one, and Palhinha still has some of the Fulham magic left, it would be a snip.

13) 🔼 Alejandro Garnacho – Manchester United to Aston Villa 
United are said to have spoken to Chelsea and Villa in an effort to lump Garnacho in as part of a deal to sign a striker. Chelsea’s valuations of Garnacho and Nicolas Jackson are miles apart, but there could be some common ground with Villa. For the purposes of PSR, they would need to be separate transactions, but Villa are in a stronger position than United given they know Garnacho has got to go somewhere before the deadline, whereas they would be quite content to keep Watkins. Regardless, there is a deal to be done here.

12) Dominic Calvert-Lewin – Everton to Aston Villa
Calvert-Lewin left Everton at the end of last season and Villa reportedly see the ex-England striker as a cheap way to bolster their attacking options. Newcastle and AC Milan are thinking along similar lines but Villa currently appear to be favourites.

11) 🔽 Ollie Watkins – Aston Villa to Manchester United
This one picked up again after reports that United are to choose between Watkins and Benjamin Sesko. Of course, we’d expect Villa might want a say in that. And, if asked, they’d say they want £60million. United, apparently, reckon they can get Villa down to around £45million. But they thought they could haggle with Brentford and ended up paying more for Bryan Mbeumo. Watkins might find himself as United’s preferred option just because they could offer Garnacho to Villa.

10) James McAtee – Manchester City to Nottingham Forest 
Forest are said to have had a bid rejected for the England Under-21 star, whose minutes at City are threatened by Rayan Cherki’s arrival. McAtee has interest from Eintracht Frankfurt and Borussia Dortmund, while Palace are keen too. But Forest aren’t far off with their £25million bid. We suspect this will come down to the player’s preference: stay in the Premier League, or a gap season or two in Europe?

9) 🔼 Yoane Wissa – Brentford to Newcastle
Newcastle are having a ‘mare of a summer, but some rare good news came in the form of Wissa’s desire to move to St James’ Park. However, and quite reasonably, we’ll add, Brentford are intent on keeping the forward having already lost their manager, captain and best player this summer. If Newcastle really want Wissa, they’ll have to pay over £40m for a player who was reportedly told last summer that he could leave for £26m at the end of 2024/25, prompting him to go on strike. With Brentford due back in London from their pre-season camp, we can expect some clarity here soon. The Bees have shown they are no pushover but Wissa isn’t f***ing around either.

8) 🔽 Benjamin Sesko – RB Leipzig to Newcastle
If Newcastle get a massive fee for Isak, you can bet any discount Leipzig were offering on Sesko will be voided. Let’s say the Toon get £120million for Isak and they spend £75million on Sesko and cover the Anthony Elanga fee. Is that so terrible? Regardless, Newcastle’s interest in Sesko goes back a year and some reports suggest personal terms are already sorted. But Man Utd’s interest complicates matters. The worst-case summer scenario for Newcastle could become a grim reality.

7) Jadon Sancho – Manchester United to Juventus
It was reported ages ago that agreements had been reached between the clubs and the player, but still we wait. The reason, we suspect, is Juve stalling for time. They do need to sell, but they also know there is no other market for Sancho, If they sit tight, United will grow more desperate, as might the player, and better terms will almost certainly become available. Indeed, United’s price has come down again to between £15million and £17million (so, £16million?) and Sancho’s agent was in Turin last week in a vain attempt to speed things along.

6) 🔼 Benjamin Sesko – RB Leipzig to Manchester United
On Wednesday morning, we were told that Watkins was the priority; by Wednesday evening, it’s Sesko. As always, it seems United are fighting themselves, with some lobbying for Watkins, while head of recruitment Christopher Vivell is pushing for the player he’s credited with signing for RB Leipzig six years ago. Has anyone asked Ruben Amorim? Either way, players are “scared” to join Newcastle and not a team that just finished 15th in the Premier League. United’s boost is Newcastle’s blow.

5) Eberechi Eze – Crystal Palace to Arsenal
Viktor Gyokeres is signed, sealed and delivered and the feeling during that saga was that Eze would be the Gunners’ next target. The England star has, apparently, been telling his mates he’s moving to the Emirates, but Arsenal now need to deliver on Palace’s clear demand for his £68million buy-out clause to be met. Cue Andrea Berta haggling for weeks over the number of instalments. And the Gunners need to sell first.

4) Alexander Isak – Newcastle to Liverpool
Newcastle and Liverpool are currently at a stand-off, with Isak in the middle. Newcastle have received no bid yet, and the Reds are holding fire, knowing that time only increases the pressure on the Magpies. They are still intent on digging in, even if it means convincing Isak to stay for one more season, and are unlikely to sanction a sale without having a replacement sorted first. Sesko is their top target, but Man United are also there.. Given Isak left it so late to declare his wishes and Liverpool have already signed a striker in his place, it is easy to imagine this being kicked down the road until next summer. For now we wait until Liverpool show their hand.

3) 🔼 Xavi Simons – RB Leipzig to Chelsea
A Chelsea move appeals to Simons and the Blues are keen to make it happen. But first they need to raise some cash and even then, they will look for a hefty discount on the £56million RB Leipzig are demanding for the Arsenal target.

2)  Jorrel Hato – Ajax to Chelsea
This one is edging towards completion, with personal terms and a fee agreed. Liverpool and Arsenal were both keen, and Real Madrid were also linked, but Chelsea have been more decisive than any of them.

1) Aaron Ramsdale – Southampton to Newcastle
Newcastle faffed about all summer before eventually being elbowed out of the James Trafford race by Manchester City. So having missed out on one England keeper to replace their England keeper, they want a different England keeper, Ramsdale is having a medical on Thursday before the Toon pay £4million to borrow him for the season with the option of a more permanent arrangement.

headline: Xabi Alonso ‘wants’ Man Utd star as Real Madrid ‘open door’ to shock £142m PL double swoop
body: Xabi Alonso has his eye on two Premier League midfielders as Real Madrid ‘open the door’ to a double swoop which would cost Los Blancos £142m.

Madrid have spent around £150m so far this summer, with Trent Alexander-Arnold, Dean Huijsen, Franco Mastantuono and Alvaro Carreras all arriving to bolster the squad ahead of Alonso’s first season at the helm.

The former Bayer Leverkusen manager is thought to be keen on adding a target man to his ranks in the mould of ex-Madrid striker Joselu, but is also after a new midfielder who can dictate play from the base of midfield, as he used to do in his time at the Bernabeu.

They’ve been linked with Manchester City’s Rodri, Chelsea’s Enzo Fernández and Liverpool star Alexis Mac Allister, but there’s said to be ‘reluctance’ from president Florentino Perez to make such a ‘galactic’ signing this summer, with the Madrid boss ‘opening the door to a planned signing with pause and measure’.
Defensa Central don’t explicitly say that means the La Liga giants are happy to wait until next year to sign a new defensive midfielder, but that’s the implication.
And Manchester United star Kobbie Mainoo is said to be one of two Premier League players Alonso ‘wants’ amid a ‘change in focus’ to ‘alternatives more focused on the future’.

After a report last week claimed Tottenham had ‘made contact’ with United over a possible move for Mainoo – who was previously valued at £70m by the Red Devils, but is now thought to be available for just £42m – manager Ruben Amorim warned the academy graduate that he won’t be a guaranteed starter next season unless he increases his tempo of play.
Amorim said: “I think he can play in both positions [No 6 and No 10] in the midfield. Last year, he played more in front.

“His perfect position is more near the ball, always with the ball. He’s a big talent, and you guys know better than me that he is a big talent. He needs to increase the rhythm, the pace. I’m always on top of that with Kobbie because he is so good sometimes, but he can be better.

“So I have big plans but, like I said, it’s one game per week and the competition is going to be huge. Everybody has to be prepared to play one game, or play all the games, that is a key point in our season.”
The Spanish outlet also names Crystal Palace star Adam Wharton as another midfielder Alonso is a big admirer of.

It was claimed last month that Wharton is ‘ready to wait’ for Liverpool to come calling next summer amid interest from Tottenham, with Palace currently not willing to listen to offers for their £100m man with the futures of both Eberechi Eze and Marc Guehi in doubt.
The report adds:

‘Both players are old acquaintances of the Madrid skimmers. The scouting team that responds to Juni Calafat has always maintained a follow-up of promising young people in the Premier League, where the names of the Crystal Palace midfielder and the Manchester United midfielder, respectively, always stood out.

‘In England, as we have been able to see from Central Defense, they understand that Real Madrid is looking for an incorporation for the near future. The progression of Adam Wharton and Kobbie Mainoo is brilliant, but they have not yet stood out enough to integrate into the orbit of the football elite of the Old Continent. That is why the follow-up carried out to date will be intensified under the orders of Xabi Alonso.’

These 10 guys are the best defensive midfielders available to sign this summer. Only three Premier League players are on offer…
Liverpool are reportedly the ‘favourites’ to land the Crystal Palace star, who’s ‘ready to wait’ for a Reds bid rather than moving to Tottenham.
Mainoo is so much more than ‘pure profit’ and the very idea of selling him is an indictment of Premier League profit and sustainability rules.

headline: Ruben Amorim hints at no further Man Utd transfers with ‘really happy’ claim
body: Ruben Amorim has hinted Man Utd may do no further business in the striker transfer market despite being heavily linked with Ollie Watkins and Benjamin Sesko.

Just 44 goals last season, a tally only worsened by the relegated clubs and Everton, had every Man Utd fan crying out for new signings and while the club have already landed Bryan Mbeumo and Matheus Cunha, there is still a desire to sign an out-and-out number nine.
Aston Villa’s Watkins and RB Leipzig’s Sesko are thought to be the leading candidates but head coach Amroim has hinted the club may stick with their current options, most notably Rasmus Hojlund.
“I’m really happy with Rasmus,” Amorim said after his side beat Bournemouth 4-1 in Chicago.

“I don’t know what is going to happen until the end of the market. The important thing is that the strikers that are here are working really well, are improving, are helping the team and that is the most important thing.”
Amorim also said that while goals have been a problem for the Dane, he helps the team in other areas such as holding the ball up and bringing others into play.
“People focus on the goals and we suffer a lot because of the lack of goals,” Amorim said.
“I think not just the goals, but the way he connects the play every time we have to kick the ball.
“The ability for him to hold the defender and to connect in support is helping us a lot to play better and we are playing better because he’s playing better.”

headline: Wayne Rooney ‘work ethic’ questioned in Tom Brady ‘lazy and entitled’ assessment
body: Wayne Rooney’s work ethic has been questioned by his former boss Tom Brady who also said the Birmingham squad was “lazy and entitled.”
The NFL Hall of Famer co-owns the Blues and his damning assessment has been revealed as part of a new Amazon Prime documentary set to air on Friday.
Brady questioned Rooney’s work ethic before passing judgment on a Birmingham squad that was relegated to League One in 2024.
“I’m a little worried about our head coach’s work ethic,” he said, as per the BBC. “I mean, I don’t know, I don’t have great instincts on that.”
Rooney’s time at Birmingham was difficult from the off having replaced John Eustace who had the Blues sixth in the Championship.
Rooney lost his first game, against former team-mate Michael Carrick, and had to wait until late November for his first win.
The England forward was then given the sack in January having picked up just two wins in 15 games and with the club in 20th.
As for the players, Brady blamed them for Birmingham’s relegation, suggesting they did not put in enough effort to stay up.
“Well we’ve already changed the coach, so it’s really the players because the coach doesn’t go out there and put the ball in the goal,” he said.
“They were lazy, they were entitled and when you’re lazy and entitled, you don’t have much of a chance to succeed.
“We’ve got to change all the people that are associated with losing, so I think this summer there’s going to be a lot of people gone.”
Another scene shows Rooney and Brady discussing the team’s plight with the former Man Utd striker suggesting it was a concentration issue.
“Why they’re playing in the Championship and not the Premier League,” Rooney said, “is because… we’ve all passed a ball, kicked the ball and run, but it’s a focus, concentrated for 90 minutes.”
Brady did at least admit some blame, suggesting the new ownership changed too much, too quickly.
“There was some good advice that I got that was like, ‘listen, don’t go in there and make these big, sweeping changes – you guys have time’,” he said.
“And of course we make sweeping changes.”
